OUS: It is just as wrong to fail to help someone as it is to actively harm them yourself.
Answers kodonho/SolarM-SakuraSolar-SLERP: Answer: 6 - Agree. While the act of causing harm is inherently negative the concept of not providing aid or assistance when one has the ability to do so can also have negative consequences for others. Both actions can result in suffering and can be considered morally wrong.
Answers abideen/NexoNimbus-7B OUS: I agree with the statement.  The statement is a reflection of the moral principle of non-maleficence which is one of the four principles of biomedical ethics. Non-maleficence states that one should not intentionally harm others but it also includes the idea that one should not fail to act when they have the ability to prevent harm. This principle is often associated with the Hippocratic Oath which states "I will not give a lethal drug to anyone if I am asked nor will I advise such a plan." This oath emphasizes the importance of not only avoiding active harm but also ensuring that one does not fail to prevent harm when they have the ability to do so.
